column2: About three weeks ago my best friend gets kicked out of her house along with her child and she came to me for help. I gladly accepted her and her child to stay at my home rent free until she is ready to go on. My bestfriend and her husband had a huge falling out. I felt extremely guilty. I allowed her to stay at my house for three weeks now. All she has done for me is take and take from me without ever giving. I figured that she was hurt and not in a good place, so I allowed it. After day in and day out of her not cleaning after herself or her son, not helping around the house, and not being a decent roommate is where I feel like I could have done something.
column5: Approximately three weeks prior, my best friend and her child were supposedly kicked out of their home, and she supposedly sought my help. Allegedly, I welcomed them into my home rent-free while she supposedly got back on her feet. My best friend and her husband had an alleged major argument, and I supposedly felt extremely guilty. For what seems like three weeks now, she and her child have allegedly stayed with me. Allegedly, all she has done is take endlessly without offering anything in return. I allegedly assumed she was upset and in a challenging place, so I supposedly tolerated it. Day after day of her supposedly not cleaning or helping around the house and her alleged lack of consideration as a roommate is reportedly when I supposedly felt I could have acted differently.

column2: Two weeks ago, we buried my mother in law. It was a sad day that day. My father had a few tears. My mother had a few more tears. My brothers and sisters all gave me a hug. I gave a speech about her life. She was an accountant. She always went to work with a smile. She always got the job done. She was the best accountant at the company. She had a few kids and a husband. They all loved her. She loved to eat cupcakes. She loved them if they had some sprinkles on them. We celebrated this by having a giant batch of cupcakes made for the burial. We all grabbed a cupcake and threw them into the grave before she was buried.
column5: A couple of weeks ago, we held a ceremony for my mother-in-law's burial. It was an emotional day. My father shed a few tears, while my mother cried a bit more. My siblings all embraced me, and I delivered a speech celebrating her life. She worked as an accountant and always approached her job with a cheerful demeanor. Her efficiency made her the top accountant at her firm. With several children and a husband, she was deeply cherished by her family. She had a fondness for cupcakes, especially those adorned with sprinkles. To honor her memory, we ordered a large batch of cupcakes for the burial. As part of the ceremony, we each took a cupcake and tossed them into the grave before proceeding with the burial.
